newsitem.title: CANADA: Canadian bonds open mixed amid lack of fresh data.
newsitem.headline: Canadian bonds open mixed amid lack of fresh data.

text.p: Canadian bonds opened little changed on Monday, with volumes light amid a lack of fresh economic data and many traders focused on activity in the long end of the curve, analysts said.

"There's not much news, certainly nothing out of the U.S. and nothing out of Canada on the economic front," said Rich Wylie, a fixed-income economist with TD Securities Inc. "Most of what people are going to be looking at today is Canada's long end spread."
Canada's 30-year benchmark bond rose C$0.03 to C$116.37 to yield 6.723 percent.

The U.S. 30-year bond rose 5/32 to yield 6.71 percent. The spread between the bonds moved to one basis point from zero on Friday. On Thursday, the Canada-U.S. 30-year spread went negative for the first time in history.

"We're doing what we've done in most of the other terms as the Canadian curve has broken through the U.S. curve," said Wylie. "We expect to see the 30-year rate back underneath that in the U.S. over the near term for sure."
With no major Canadian or U.S. economic reports out this morning and a heavy calendar of data out this week, analysts said today's session is expected to be quiet.
Key economic reports out this week include Canada's consumer price index report for May on Tuesday and the retails sales report for April on Thursday.
U.S. economic reports out this week expected to affect the the market include their consumer price index report for May, also on Tuesday, and the Fed Beige book on Wednesday.
In other prices, Canada's 10-year benchmark bond rose C$0.11 to C$108.13 to yield 6.145 percent while the U.S. 10-year rose 4/32 to 6.41 percent.
The negative spread between the bonds widened to 27 basis points from 25 basis points at Friday's close.
The three-month cash T-bill yielded 2.82 percent against its U.S. equivalent which yielded 4.95 percent.
